title: Roy Keane slams 'shocking and abysmal' Danny Rose after England defeat
text:
The Tottenham defender did not have his best game in an England shirt (Picture: Reuters)

Manchester United legend Roy Keane has torn into Danny Rose for his performance in England’s shock defeat to Czech Republic on Friday night in Prague.

The Three Lions lost a tournament qualifier for the first time in 10 years as they succumbed to a 2-1 defeat, with 30-year-old debutant Zdenek Ondrasek getting the winner for the hosts late on.

England gave one of their worst performances under Gareth Southgate in a laboured display, though Keane was quick to single out Rose – at fault for the winner – as being particularly bad.

Ondrasek celebrates his winner against England in Prague on Friday night (Picture: Getty)

‘Rose gave a performance tonight, my goodness, someone has got to get a hold of that guy. He was shocking, abysmal,’ he said on punditry duty for ITV after the game.

‘I think he’ll be the same in another three or four years.

‘Some players don’t learn from their mistakes, that’s a big problem and at the highest level you will suffer for it.’

Keane says England, and Rose especially, could have done better for the Czech Republic’s decisive second goal, while he felt the performance as whole was poor.

‘I think there was a lot of frustration,’ the Irishman explained.

‘I don’t think England looked right from the start of the game, and that can happen in football. You go away from home, it’s going to be difficult. But they didn’t look right, they didn’t seem sharp.

Keane felt England could have easily stopped the hosts from scoring their winner (Picture: Getty)

‘There was a lot of bickering going on before the end, which is fine, because players are upset, and they’re pointing the finger at each other.

‘You’re five minutes away from getting a draw, which is not the end of the world, and there’s almost a bit of arrogance from England.

‘Danny Rose was never going to win a header, there was more chance of me winning a header than him.

‘And then [Harry] Maguire, for a guy with his experience, you have to smell and sense danger in a football game, and he strolls out. Get up to people! It just summed up the whole night for England.’
